description: From Middle English fredom, freedom, from Old English frēodōm (“freedom, state of free-will, charter, emancipation, deliverance”), from Proto-West Germanic *frijadōm (“freedom”). Equivalent to free +‎ -dom. Cognate with North Frisian fridoem (“freedom”), Dutch vrijdom (“freedom”), Low German frīdom (“freedom”), Middle High German vrītuom (“freedom”), Norwegian fridom (“freedom”).

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The state of being free, of not being imprisoned or enslaved.
examples: Having recently been released from prison, he didn't know what to do with his newfound freedom.

entries.meaning: (countable) The lack of a specific constraint, or of constraints in general; a state of being free, unconstrained.
The right or privilege of unrestricted use or access
Improper familiarity; violation of the rules of decorum.
examples: "A first love is not easily extinguished, Mr. Allanson," said she. "You may guess from my appearance, that I have been fortunate in life; but, for all that, my first love for you has continued the same, unaltered and unchanged, and you must forgive the little freedoms I used to-day to try your affections, and the effects my appearance would have on you."
